saved_resources.name: CPLC Parenting Arizona
saved_resources.subtext: Home Visitation, Parenting Classes, and Parent Aide Services
saved_resources.summary: All Programs are offered in English and Spanish. The Home Visitation program is for families with children ages birth to 3 years old. The program focuses on child health and development, parenting skills, and linkage to community resources. Parenting classes are open to families with children ages birth to 18 years old. The focus is on strengthening parenting skills and linkage to community resources. School Choice links families with high quality schools in their area and educates families on the importance of finding the right school for their child.

saved_resources.name: Arizona Department of Education
saved_resources.summary: Raising Special Kids is a 501 (c )3 non-profit organization that provides support and information for parents of children, from birth to age 26, with a full range of disabilities and special health care needs. Programs are offered at no cost to families, and are available in English and Spanish.

resources.name: CPLC Parenting Arizona
resources.summary: The Guadalupe Family Resource Center offers the following services in both English and Spanish: parenting classes, monthly group socials, food box vouchers, a computerlab for families to use the internet, AHCCCS Insurance assistance, Nutrition Assistance, TANF assistance, WIC services, and School Choice assistance.

resources.name: Arizona Department of Child Safety
resources.summary: Department of Child Safety (DCS), formerly CPS, is a program mandated by law whose primary purpose is to protect children who are abused and/or neglected. This program provides specialized welfare services that seek to prevent, abuse and/or neglect of children and address dependency issues. The Department of Child Safety program receives, screens and investigates allegations of child abuse and neglect, performs assessments of child safety, assesses the imminent risk of harm to the children and evaluates conditions that support or refute the alleged abuse or neglect and need for emergency intervention. This program also provides services designed to stabilize a family in crisis and to preserve the family unit by reducing safety and risk factors. This program provides an array of services, Team Decision Making, Family Preservation Services (Intensive Family Services), High-Risk Infant Services and a Substance Exposed Newborn Safe Environment program (in Maricopa County), case management, parent aide, substance abuse assessment and treatment (Arizona Families F.I.R.S.T.) and other in-home family support services. Not all programs are offered in every geographic area. In addition, services to promote permanence, stability and continuity of care are provided for children who enter out-of-home care. Services include, but are not limited to case management, permanency planning, provision of out-of-home care, kinship foster care, adoptive and foster homes.

resources.name: Arizona Department of Education
resources.summary: Raising Special Kids is a 501 (c )3 non-profit organization that provides support and information for parents of children, from birth to age 26, with a full range of disabilities and special health care needs. Programs are offered at no cost to families, and are available in English and Spanish.

resources.name: Baylight Institute for Creative Arts
resources.subtext: Music and Art Classes for Children and Adults
resources.summary: Offering music and art classes for children and adults, private and group, after school, after work. Offering Free Community Events such as Free Music / Art Movie Night 3rd Tuesday, Free Open Mic Night 2nd Friday, and Free Art / Music Demo Weekend Third Weekend of Month.

resources.name: Aid to Adoption of Special Kids (Main Office)
resources.subtext: Foster Care, Adoption, Mentoring, Home and Community Based Services
resources.summary: AASK offers traditional foster care and specialized foster care programs for developmentally disabled, medically fragile and tribal affiliated children. AASK’s Kinship foster care program provides unlicensed relative families with immediate case management services and support while they complete the licensing or certification processes. We have bilingual, culturally relevant services to Latino families. The 30-hour required licensing class (PS-MAPP) is offered in English and Spanish. This training is presented at each of our 3 locations at various days and times. Accelerated class schedules (6-8 weeks) are available. The AASK Mentoring & Sibling Program connects youth with caring, supportive adults. We believe it is important for AASK foster families, adoptive families, and mentors to know they can have quick and convenient access to us. A dedicated staff focuses on providing the annual 144 hours of respite authorized for foster families. An after-hours emergency number keeps you connected to us 24/7/365.
